awd_titl_txt: Making in the Maker Movement: An Investigation into the Impact of Additive Manufacturing on Student Creativity
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive Manufacturing (synonymous with 3D printing) is a process in which successive layers of material are deposited under computer control to create a three-dimensional artifact. The field is estimated to grow to a worldwide revenue of more than $21 billion by the year 2020. While additive manufacturing (AM) is projected to form an important part of the United States' future global manufacturing competitiveness, current industry demands for a skilled AM workforce are not being met. This has lead to universities ramping up their AM course offerings and engineering educators using AM technologies to augment prototyping and manufacturing learning during the design process. Unfortunately, there is no rigorous scientific understanding of the best approach to formally educate students with AM in the classroom or evaluate effective instructional practices. As a result, instructor efforts may not be properly preparing students to utilize AM to improve their designs, a growing area of research termed Design for Additive Manufacturing (DfAM). To address this educational gap, the objective in this project is to understand how formal undergraduate AM educational approaches impact design learning and creativity in engineering students. This will be determined through evaluation of student design novelty and feasibility as they participate in a variety of DfAM educational units and design activities. 

The research questions to be investigated address the impact on student creativity  of (i) type of AM instruction; (ii) complexity of design task and (iii) educational level of student. Participants will complete a pre-AM knowledge test, participate in AM training sessions, produce ideas and models for a design challenge and complete a post-AM knowledge test. Standard metrics for creativity assessment such as the Shah, Vargas-Hernandez and Smith metric for novelty, quality and feasibility will be employed.
The best practices identified through this research will inform the creation of a formal DfAM educational intervention in engineering design courses that accounts for the findings in the areas of content focus, design task complexity and structure, activity duration, and student educational level. This will help engineering educators prepare their students with the necessary knowledge, skills, and experiences for the nascent AM workforce, and can be expanded to understand similar effects in Maker Spaces, K-12 education, and industry settings.

por.por_cntn:
Additive manufacturing (AM) processes are a group of manufacturing technologies that build parts by processing material layer-by-layer. These processes starkly contrast against traditional, subtractive manufacturing processes, which manufacture parts by removing material from stock material. AM processes present designers with unique manufacturing capabilities, previously impossible with traditional manufacturing. To help designers leverage these design freedoms, researchers have proposed design techniques collectively known as opportunistic design for AM (DfAM). On the other hand, AM processes also present characteristic limitations that impact the manufacturability of AM solutions. To help designers overcome the limitations of AM, researchers have proposed design tools and methods collectively known as restrictive DfAM. As AM processes become more ubiquitous in engineering, design, and manufacturing, there has emerged a need for a workforce skilled in designing for AM. Such an AM and DfAM-skilled workforce must particularly be skilled in creatively leveraging the offerings of AM processes.

The overall objective in this research was to explore this research gap by studying the effects of variations in a DfAM educational intervention -- comprising content presentations and design tasks -- on student learning and creativity. Specifically, the effects of four components of a DfAM educational intervention were tested: (1) the content and order of DfAM information presentation, (2) the definition of the AM design task, (3) the competitive structure of the AM design task, and (4) the length of the combined content presentation and design task. The effects of variations in these components were tested through experiments with over 900 students across educational levels (i.e., first-year, third-year, and fourth-year) in mechanical engineering.

The first key contribution from this work is that it demonstrates the potential presence of recall inhibition on designers' learning and recall of DfAM knowledge in engineering design. Moreover, the research suggests that the order of DfAM content presentation can be used as a potential strategy for alleviating recall inhibition. This finding also supports the study of information structuring in designers and the role of prior experience and familiarity with information (e.g., with experienced fourth-year students) on designers' ability to recall and use information in engineering design.

The second key contribution is that this work highlights the importance of choosing appropriate problems when introducing DfAM educational interventions. Specifically, this work suggests that design problems with explicit constraints and objectives give students the opportunity to be creative in their DfAM use and provides them with a direction to apply their creativity. This finding is particularly important when introducing DfAM in real-world contexts, wherein design problems are often complex with numerous interacting objectives and constraints. Consequently, designers must frame problems such that they have sufficient creative freedom, but also have sufficient direction for creatively applying domain knowledge (e.g., through objectives and constraints).

Third, this work suggests that opportunistic DfAM training has the potential to support creativity in engineering design; however, designers must be sufficiently motivated to leverage this creative potential. Moreover, external rewards could be used as a potential strategy to trigger designers' task motivation. This finding is particularly important as designers could demonstrate different levels of motivation (e.g., at the individual, team, and organizational level). Consequently, accounting for and leveraging these different levels of motivation, both, internal and external, could be used to encourage creativity through DfAM.

Finally, this work also contributes the DfAM self-efficacy scale -- a validated measure for evaluating student learning of DfAM concepts in conceptual design. This scale could be used by educators to evaluate student learning and by design and education researchers to evaluate the effectiveness of design and educational interventions in DfAM. Additionally, through the systematic evaluation of the various components of a DfAM educational intervention, this work has resulted in the development and testing of educational presentations, design tasks, and assessment tools that are freely available for use by design and engineering educators to formulate and deploy DfAM educational interventions that support student learning and creativity.
